column3: planned attendances are excluded as these are not considered to be emergency care.¬Difference between the CCG rate for total A&E attendances and the average for the 'closest 10' CCGs or the average of the five lowest rates amongst the 'closest 10' CCGs
column4: multiplied by average unit price¬N/A¬"The 'savings potential' for each measure represents the difference between the activity rate for the selected CCG and the closest (most similar) 10 CCGs (excluding specialised commissioning)
column5: multiplied by the CCG population and the average unit price for the selected CCG for the relevant financial year. column1: Distance of closest 10 CCGs (excluding specialised commissioning) is defined as the sum of squared differences between 12 standardised demographic variables. The standardisation method is interdecile standardisation
column2: which is calculated by taking the CCG value
column3: subtracting the medium
column4: and then dividing by the difference between the 90th and 10th percentiles.

64¬Total outpatients savings potential difference between activity rate and closest 10 CCGs, by CCG¬Total outpatient attendance savings potential¬All outpatient attendances to consultant-led specific acute specialties potential savings by reducing activity levels to those seen in peer Clinical Commissioning Groups (CCGs).¬All outpatient activity is reported to give a view of the total outpatient activity level in the CCG.¬Difference between the CCG rate for total outpatient attendances and the average for the 'closest 10' CCGs or the average of the five lowest rates amongst the 'closest 10' CCGs, multiplied by average unit price¬N/A¬The 'savings potential' for each measure represents the difference between the activity rate for the selected CCG and the closest (most similar) 10 CCGs (excluding specialised commissioning)
column2: multiplied by the CCG population and the average unit price for the selected CCG for the relevant financial year. column1: Distance of closest 10 CCGs (excluding specialised commissioning) is defined as the sum of squared differences between 12 standardised demographic variables. The standardisation method is interdecile standardisation
column2: which is calculated by taking the CCG value
column3: subtracting the medium
column4: and then dividing by the difference between the 90th and 10th percentiles.

74¬First outpatients savings potential difference between activity rate and closest 10 CCGs, by CCG¬First outpatient attendance savings potential¬Outpatient first attendances to consultant-led specific acute specialties potential savings by reducing activity levels to those seen in peer Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG)s¬Outpatient activity is split between first and follow-up attendances to allow further analysis of total outpatient activity, monitoring first to follow-up trends etc in the CCG.¬Difference between the CCG rate for first outpatient attendances and the average for the 'closest 10' CCGs or the average of the five lowest rates amongst the 'closest 10' CCGs, multiplied by average unit price¬N/A¬The 'savings potential' for each measure represents the difference between the activity rate for the selected CCG and the closest (most similar) 10 CCGs (excluding specialised commissioning)
column2: multiplied by the CCG population and the average unit price for the selected CCG for the relevant financial year. A range is offered: the lower figure is based on the average for all of the closest 10 CCGs; the upper figure is based on the average for the five of the closest 10 CCGs with the lowest rates.

column1: Distance of closest 10 CCGs (excluding specialised commissioning) is defined as the sum of squared differences between 12 standardised demographic variables. The standardisation method is interdecile standardisation
column2: which is calculated by taking the CCG value
column3: subtracting the medium
column4: and then dividing by the difference between the 90th and 10th percentiles.

column2: transferred or discharged within 4 hours¬"The percentage of Accident and Emergency (A&E) attendances admitted

column5: all types of A&E are included in the measure."¬"A&E waiting times form part of the NHS Constitution. NHS England must take into account the expected rights and pledges for patients that are made in the Constitution when assessing organisational delivery. This measure aims to encourage providers to improve health outcomes and patient experience of A&E.

column1: Operational standard is 95%"¬Total number of patients who have a total time in A&E within 4 hours from arrival to admission
column2: transfer or discharge (all types of A&E)¬Total number of A&E attendances (all types of A&E)¬"The following fields from A&E attendances and emergency admissions monthly return (MSitAE via Strategic Data Collection Service (SDCS)) are required to construct the numerator: Number of A&E attendances (all types of A&E); Number of A&E attendances within 4 hours from arrival to admission
column3: transfer or discharge (all types of A&E).

column1: The following fields from A&E Hospital Episode Statistics (for mapping to CCG) are required to construct the denominator: Number of A&E attendances (all types of A&E).
Mapping A&E 4 hour standard from provider to CCG:

HES A&E data is used to estimate what proportion of activity from a provider can be attributed to each CCG. These proportions are applied to both numerator and denominator (provider based monthly collection figures on breaches and attendances) to assign numbers to each CCG. A limit of 1% is used
column2: so any percentages of less than 1% for a mapping to a CCG are ignored in the calculations. Thus the numbers of attendances / breaches does not correspond to the actual figures and should only be used as a basis for estimating performance."¬NHS England: A&E attendances and emergency admissions monthly return.¬"https://www.england.nhs.uk/statistics/statistical-work-areas/ae-waiting-times-and-activity/

187¬Starting treatment for psychosis within two weeks of referral by England (%)¬Percentage of people with first episode of psychosis starting treatment with a NICE-recommended package of care treated within 2 weeks of referral by England¬The percentage of people referred to service experiencing first episode psychosis or at risk mental state that start a NICE-recommended care package in the reporting period.
All activity relating to people who receive specialist secondary mental health care services and have
column2: or are thought to have
column3: a mental illness; or who receive specialist secondary learning disabilities or autism spectrum disorder services and have
column4: or are thought to have
column5: a learning disability or autism spectrum disorder is within scope. Children and adolescents (including those with a learning disability and/or autism spectrum disorder) under the age of 18 are also included where they are in receipt of care from a specialist secondary mental health
column6: learning disabilities or autism spectrum disorder service or an early intervention service. Children and young people in receipt of psychological therapies covered under the Children and Young People's (CYP) Improving Access to Psychological Therapies (IAPT) programme are included within the scope."¬To encourage compliance with the new access and waiting time standard. This standard came into effect on 1 April 2016 and required that more than 50% of people experiencing first episode psychosis will be treated with a NICE-concordant package of care within 2 weeks of referral rising to 60% by 1 April 2020.¬The number of people referred to the service experiencing first episode psychosis or at risk mental state that start treatment within 2 weeks of referral in the reporting period¬The number of people referred to the service experiencing first episode psychosis or at risk mental state that start treatment in the reporting period¬"Two conditions must be met for the waiting time standard to be deemed to have been achieved:

column1: 1. A maximum wait of two weeks from referral to treatment; and
2. Treatment delivered in accordance with NICE guidelines for psychosis and
schizophrenia - either in children and young people CG155 (2013) https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/CG155 or in adults CG178 (2014) https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/CG178 (last accessed 18 June 2019).
Most initial episodes of psychosis occur between early adolescence and age 25 but the standard applies to people of all ages in line with NICE guidance.
Exemptions from accessing EIP services are referrals of people who are experiencing psychotic symptoms with a confirmed organic cause
column2: for example brain diseases such as Huntingtons and Parkinsons disease
column3: HIV or syphilis
column4: dementia
column5: or brain tumours or cysts.

column1: 205¬Cancer patients seen within 2 weeks (%)¬Percentage of cancer patients seen within 14 days from an urgent GP referral for suspected cancer to a first consultant appointment¬"Percentage of patients seen within 14 days from an urgent GP referral for suspected cancer to a first consultant appointment.

Cancer waiting times performance is assessed using quarterly data.  Monthly data is also collected but this is provisional and is subject to change as records are validated within the quarter.  As a consequence the sum of the standalone published monthly data for a given quarter does not equal the equivalent standalone quarterly published data.  Data items represent the latest finalised quarterly performance data as well as the most recent monthly provisional data in order to show an indication of the progress within the quarter.  Operational standards only apply to quarterly data aggregated for all tumour categories."¬To ensure Providers and Clinical Commissioning Groups (CCGs) achieve and maintain the Constitution standard for waiting times from urgent GP referral for suspected cancer to  date first seen for all suspected cancers. The indicator is a core delivery indicator that maximum two week wait from urgent GP (GMP
column2: GDP or Optometrist) referral for suspected cancer to first outpatient attendance. ¬Patients urgently referred with suspected cancer by their GP (GMP
column3: GDP or Optometrist) who were first seen within 14 calendar days within the given month¬All patients urgently referred with suspected cancer by their GP (GMP
column4: GDP or Optometrist) who were first seen within the given month¬"The following data fields in the Cancer Waiting Times Database (CWT-Db) are used to construct the indicator: PERIOD; YEAR; DCO; CCG; ProviderCode; CancerReportCategory NoSeen; DaysWithin14; Days15to16; Days17to21; Days22To28; DaysMoreThan28; STP

206¬Cancer patients treated within 31 days (%)¬Percentage of cancer patients treated within 31 days of DTT¬Percentage of patients given a first treatment for cancer within 31 days of a decision to treat (DTT).

Cancer waiting times performance is assessed using quarterly data.  Monthly data is also collected but this is provisional and is subject to change as records are validated within the quarter.  As a consequence the sum of the standalone published monthly data for a given quarter does not equal the equivalent standalone quarterly published data.  Data items represent the latest finalised quarterly performance data as well as the most recent monthly provisional data in order to show an indication of the progress within the quarter.  Operational standards only apply to quarterly data aggregated for all tumour categories."¬To ensure Providers and Clinical Commissioning Groups (CCGs) achieve and maintain the Constitution standard for waiting times from urgent GP referral for suspected cancer to first definitive treatment. 214¬RTT patients waiting less than 18 weeks (%)¬Percentage of patients waiting 18 weeks or less from referral to hospital treatment¬The percentage of patients waiting to start non-emergency consultant-led treatment who were waiting 18 weeks or less at the end of the reporting period.

Operational standard is 92% at speciality level.

Speciality levels and their current treatment function codes are: 100: General Surgery; 101: Urology; 110: Trauma and Orthopaedics; 120: ENT; 130: Ophthalmology; 140: Oral Surgery; 150: Neurosurgery; 160: Plastic Surgery; 170: Cardiothoracic Surgery; 300: General Medicine; 301: Gastroenterology; 320: Cardiology; 330: Dermatology; 340: Respiratory Medicine; 400: Neurology; 410: Rheumatology; 430: Geriatric Medicine; 502: Gynaecology and; X01: All other TREATMENT FUNCTIONS not reported individually.
Data for any other treatment function should be aggregated and reported via the X01: All other treatment function code.  Exceptions to this rule are: Cardiothoracic Surgery

column2: transferred or discharged from A&E within 4 hours by CCG and STP¬"The percentage of Accident and Emergency (A&E) attendances admitted
column3: transferred or discharged within 4 hours (for all types of A&E).

column1: The total number of A&E attendances
column2: is defined as ""An unplanned attendance when the A&E attendance category = 1 or 3""
column3: for both total attendances
column4: and those where total time is within 4 hours
column5: all types of A&E are included in the measure.

column1: Performance is mapped from provider to Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG) and Sustainability and Transformation Partnerships (STP)"¬A&E waiting times form part of the NHS Constitution. NHS England must take into account the expected rights and pledges for patients that are made in the Constitution when assessing organisational delivery. This measure aims to encourage providers to improve health outcomes and patient experience of A&E.¬Total number of patients who have a total time in A&E within 4 hours from arrival to admission
column2: transfer or discharge (all types of A&E)¬Total number of A&E attendances (all types of A&E)¬"The following fields from A&E attendances and emergency admissions monthly return (MSitAE via Strategic Data Collection Service (SDCS)) are required to construct the numerator: Number of A&E attendances (all types of A&E); Number of A&E attendances within 4 hours from arrival to admission
column3: transfer or discharge (all types of A&E).

column1: The following fields from A&E Hospital Episode Statistics (for mapping to CCG) are required to construct the denominator: Number of A&E attendances (all types of A&E).
Mapping A&E 4 hour standard from provider to CCG:

HES A&E data is used to estimate what proportion of activity from a provider can be attributed to each CCG. These proportions are applied to both numerator and denominator (provider based monthly collection figures on breaches and attendances) to assign numbers to each CCG. A limit of 1% is used
column2: so any percentages of less than 1% for a mapping to a CCG are ignored in the calculations. Thus the numbers of attendances / breaches does not correspond to the actual figures and should only be used as a basis for estimating performance."¬"NHS England: A&E attendances and emergency admissions monthly return (MSitAE via SDCS) is used to measure A&E performance against the 4 hour measure using figures on number of attendances and number of attendances within 4 hours from arrival to admission
column3: transfer or discharge. Prior to 17/18 this data source was not published at STP level.

column1: NHS Digital: A&E Hospital Episode Statistics. A&E Hospital Episode Statistics on the number of A&E attendances at each provider and CCG is used to map provider data to CCGs and provide estimates of performance at CCG and subsequently STP level."¬"https://www.england.nhs.uk/statistics/statistical-work-areas/ae-waiting-times-and-activity/

column2: 000 registered population is calculated for every LSOA of residence

column1: The AGI is calculated for each CCG by weighted least squares using the indirectly age-standardised rate of unplanned hospitalisation per 100
column2: 000 registered population as the dependent variable; the rank of IMD 2015 (on a scale of 0 to 1) as the independent variable
column3: and the CCGs population in each LSOA as the weight. The coefficient on the rank of IMD is the slope and is called the AGI.

column1: 267¬Appropriate prescribing of antibiotics in primary care¬Proportion of appropriate prescribing of antibiotics in primary care by CCG¬"The number of antibiotics prescribed in primary care divided by the Item based Specific Therapeutic group AgeSex related Prescribing Unit STAR-PU.
For data at CCG level
column2: prescriptions written by a prescriber located in a particular CCG but dispensed outside that CCG will be included in the CCG in which the prescriber is based. Prescriptions written in England but dispensed outside England are included. Prescriptions dispensed in hospitals
column3: dental prescribing and private prescriptions are not included in the data. The data is to include prescribing by Out of Hours and Urgent Care services where relevant prescribing data is captured within NHS BSA ePACT2.

column1: The numerator represents actual population figures and do not need to be standardised. When used in conjunction with Specific Therapeutic Group Age-sex weightings Related Prescribing Units (STAR-PUs) data is comparable across Clinical Commissioning Groups (CCGs).

There are differences in the age and sex of patients for whom drugs in specific therapeutic groups are usually prescribed. STAR-PUs (Specific Therapeutic Group Age-sex weightings Related Prescribing Units) allow more accurate and meaningful comparisons within a specific therapeutic group by taking into account the types of people who will be receiving that treatment. This weighting is designed to weight individual practice or organisation populations for age and sex to allow for better comparison of prescribing patterns. The total number of Oral antibacterials (BNF 5.1 sub-set) ITEM based STAR-PUs are used as the denominator of this indicator.
STAR-PU weightings have been updated to reflect current prescribing practice
column2: based on prescribing patterns in primary care in England in 2013. These were made available and introduced into national prescribing data sets in February 2014."¬The purpose of this indicator is to encourage an improvement in appropriate antibiotic prescribing in primary care. Antimicrobial resistant infections impact on patient safety and the quality of patient care. Evidence suggests that antimicrobial resistance (AMR) is driven by over-using antibiotics and prescribing them inappropriately. Reducing the inappropriate use of antibiotics will delay the development of antimicrobial resistance that leads to patient harm from infections that are harder and more costly to treat. Reducing inappropriate antibiotic use will also protect patients from healthcare acquired infections such as Clostridium difficile infections.¬Total number of prescription items for antibacterial drugs (BNF 5.1) within the CCG in the previous 12 months.¬Total number of Oral antibacterials (BNF 5.1 sub-set) ITEM based Specific Therapeutic group Age-Sex Related Prescribing Units (STAR-PUs) for the previous 12 months.¬"From the Antibiotic quality premium monitoring dashboard Antibiotics STAR PU 13 tab

column1: 288¬Women's experience of maternity services¬Score for women's experiences of maternity services by CCG¬"Womens experiences of maternity services based on the Care Quality Commission (CQC) National Maternity Services Survey.
Women were eligible for the survey if they had a live birth within the sampling period
column2: were aged 16 or older and gave birth in a hospital
column3: birth centre or maternity unit
column4: or had a home birth.

column1: The indicator is a composite value
column2: calculated as the average of six survey questions from the survey
column3: and is based on responses for which the patients Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG) of registration is available. Responses to the survey reflect women who gave birth during January or February of the reference year.  The six survey questions are:

column1: 1. During your antenatal check-ups
column2: were you given enough time to ask questions or discuss your pregnancy? Answer options: yes always; yes sometimes; no; dont know.

column1: 2. Thinking about your antenatal care
column2: were you involved enough in decisions about your care? Answer options: yes always; yes sometimes; no; dont know/cant remember.

column1: 3. Were you (and/or your partner or a companion) left alone by midwives or doctors at a time when it worried you? Answer options: yes during early labour; yes during the later stages of labour; yes during the birth; yes shortly after the birth; no not at all.
4. If you raised a concern during labour and birth
column2: did you feel that it was taken seriously? Answer options: yes; no; I did not raise any concerns.

column1: 5. Thinking about the care you received in hospital after the birth of your baby
column2: were you treated with kindness and understanding? Answer options: yes always; yes sometimes; no; dont know/cant remember.

column1: 6. Did you feel that midwives and other carers gave you active support and encouragement about feeding your baby? Answer options: yes always; yes sometimes; no; I did not want/need this; dont know/cant remember."¬Patient experience is one of the three domains of quality care
column2: along with safety and clinical effectiveness. The purpose of this indicator is to encourage the improvement of patient experience in maternity services and support people to shape and manage their own health and care. To help service users make meaningful choices to achieve better health outcomes
column3: progressing towards a person-centred NHS. This indicator strives to measure patient experience across the entirety of the maternity pathway
column4: that is
column5: antenatal
column6: intrapartum and postnatal stages.¬The sum of the standardised CCG scores for the six specified questions.¬The number of questions included within the composite indicator (6).¬The following fields are required to facilitate calculation of the indicator composite scores: Code of the CCG billed for the care of respondent; Anonymised respondent record number (for a count of number of records. This is a unique identifier for each record in the data set. It does not enable identification of the patient); Age and parity grouping of respondent; Status of response (responded/did not respond).¬CQC National Maternity Services Survey.¬"https://www.cqc.org.uk/publications/surveys/maternity-services-survey-2017

column2: 0 if not. These are multiplied by the weighting allocated to respondents. The standardised mean score for each CCG per question is then calculated. Calculating respondent level proportions  divide national proportion of respondents in their age or parity group by corresponding CCG proportion.

A maximum weighting cap is assigned to limit excessive weight being given to respondents in an extremely under-represented group. column4: which enable CCGs to demonstrate they meet their statutory duties.¬N/A¬"Assessors from the NHS England Public Participation Team collect publicly-available information from CCG websites that evidences how they comply with their statutory responsibilities and the following related ten key actions:

column1: 1. Involve the public in governance

column1: 6. Feedback and Evaluate

10. Hold providers to account
The assessor reviews the CCGs most recent annual report
column2: Constitution
column3: involvement web pages
column4: engagement strategy and action plan
column5: governing body minutes
column6: equality and diversity strategy
column7: and other relevant information publicly available on the internet. The assessment takes 2-7 hours depending on the accessibility of the information.

column1: The collected information is reviewed against the assessment framework
column2: consisting of 49 criteria
column3: agreed by the Public Participation Working Group and linked to the statutory duties and key actions. Criteria are grouped under the following 5 domains:

column1: Domain A: Governance
1: Involve the public in governance
7: Implement assurance and improvement systems
10: Hold providers to account
Domain B: Annual Reporting
3. Demonstrate public involvement in Annual Reports
Domain C: Practice
2: Explain public involvement in commissioning plans
4: Promote and publicise public involvement
5: Assess
column2: plan and take action to involve

column1: 9: Provide support for effective engagement
Domain D: Feedback and Evaluation
6: Feedback and Evaluate
Domain E: Equalities and Health Inequalities

8: Advance equality and reduce health inequality"¬CCG websites¬CCG dependent¬CCG¬Annually¬Annually¬Net¬N/A¬N/A¬N/A¬N/A¬N/A¬Net¬Not in publication¬"The scoring process for each domain assesses the CCG as meeting or not meeting individual criteria
column2: and then as: Inadequate
column3: Requires Improvement
column4: Good or Outstanding for each domain. Ratings from the 5 domains are taken to give an overall score out of 15 and a RAG rating for the CCG.

column1: The detailed scoring process is as follows. The assessor reviews the available evidence against each criterion in the good category. In order to achieve good the CCG needs to meet a minimum number of criteria for the domain
column2: as follows:

column1: Domain A = 3 criteria met of 4
Domain B = 4 criteria met of 5
Domain C = 5 criteria met of 7
Domain D = 3 criteria met of 3
Domain E = 4 criteria met of 5
If a CCG does not meet good for the domain it is rated either as requires improvement subject to meeting the necessary criteria
column2: or as inadequate.

column1: In order to achieve outstanding the CCG needs first to achieve the good rating for that domain
column2: then to meet a minimum number of criteria in the outstanding category (in addition to having met good) as follows:

column1: Domain A = 3 criteria met of 4
Domain B = 1 criteria met of 1
Domain C = 3 criteria met of 4
Domain D = 3 criteria met of 3
Domain E = 3 criteria met of 3
Ratings across each domain are scored as follows (0 = Inadequate
column2: 1 = Requires Improvement
column3: 2 = Good
column4: 3 = Outstanding). These scores are totalled to reach a maximum score of 15. RAG ratings are determined using the following bandings 0-4 = RED
column5: 5-9 = AMBER
column6: 10-13= GREEN
column7: 14-15 = GREEN STAR. If a CCG scores inadequate in any category it is not possible to achieve above an AMBER rating. If a CCG achieves two or more requires improvement it is not possible to achieve more than an AMBER rating."¬Up¬¬NHSE/I¬OIC¬Fiona Leat¬-¬¬¬0¬Improvement and Assessment Framework¬0¬Structure¬Clinical Commissioning Groups

column1: 367¬Cancer percentage seen within 2 weeks¬Percentage of cancer patients seen within 14 days from an urgent GP referral for suspected cancer to a first consultant appointment¬"Percentage of patients seen within 14 days from an urgent GP referral for suspected cancer to a first consultant appointment.

Cancer waiting times performance is assessed using quarterly data.  Monthly data is also collected but this is provisional and is subject to change as records are validated within the quarter.  As a consequence the sum of the standalone published monthly data for a given quarter does not equal the equivalent standalone quarterly published data.  Data items represent the latest finalised quarterly performance data as well as the most recent monthly provisional data in order to show an indication of the progress within the quarter.  Operational standards only apply to quarterly data aggregated for all tumour categories.

Operational standard is 93%"¬To ensure Providers and Clinical Commissioning Groups (CCGs) achieve and maintain the Constitution standard for waiting times from urgent GP referral for suspected cancer to  date first seen for all suspected cancers. The indicator is a core delivery indicator that maximum two week wait from urgent GP (GMP
column2: GDP or Optometrist) referral for suspected cancer to first outpatient attendance.  ¬Patients urgently referred with suspected cancer by their GP (GMP
column3: GDP or Optometrist) who were first seen within 14 calendar days within the given month¬All patients urgently referred with suspected cancer by their GP (GMP
column4: GDP or Optometrist) who were first seen within the given month¬"The following data fields in the CWT-Db are used to construct the indicator: PERIOD; YEAR; DCO; CCG; ProviderCode; CancerReportCategory NoSeen; DaysWithin14; Days15to16; Days17to21; Days22To28; DaysMoreThan28; STP

369¬Cancer percentage treated within 31 days¬Percentage of cancer patients treated within 31 days of DTT¬Percentage of patients given a first treatment for cancer within 31 days of a decision to treat (DTT).

Cancer waiting times performance is assessed using quarterly data.  Monthly data is also collected but this is provisional and is subject to change as records are validated within the quarter.  As a consequence the sum of the standalone published monthly data for a given quarter does not equal the equivalent standalone quarterly published data.  Data items represent the latest finalised quarterly performance data as well as the most recent monthly provisional data in order to show an indication of the progress within the quarter.  Operational standards only apply to quarterly data aggregated for all tumour categories.

Cancer waiting times performance is assessed using quarterly data.  Monthly data is also collected but this is provisional and is subject to change as records are validated within the quarter. 381¬Cancer percentage treated within 62 days (quarterly)¬Percentage of cancer patients given a first treatment within 62 days from an urgent GP referral for suspected cancer by quarter¬Percentage of patients given a first treatment within 62 days from an urgent GP referral for suspected cancer.

Cancer waiting times performance is assessed using quarterly data.  Monthly data is also collected but this is provisional and is subject to change as records are validated within the quarter.  As a consequence the sum of the standalone published monthly data for a given quarter does not equal the equivalent standalone quarterly published data.  Data items represent the latest finalised quarterly performance data as well as the most recent monthly provisional data in order to show an indication of the progress within the quarter.  Operational standards only apply to quarterly data aggregated for all tumour categories.
Tumour types are breast
column2: urological (excluding testicular)
column3: lower gastrointestinal (GI)
column4: skin
column5: lung and all cancer.

column1: Specialist Trusts are not included due to case mix and small numbers."¬Number of incidences of Clostridium difficile (total cases) or the number of incidences of Clostridium difficile (Trust apportioned cases)¬N/A¬"Any of the following defines a C. difficile infection case in patients aged 2 years and above and must be reported to the Health Protection Agency:
1. Diarrhoeal stools (Bristol Stool types 5-7) where the specimen is C. difficile toxin positive;
2. Toxic megacolon or ileostomy where the specimen is C. difficile toxin positive;
3. Pseudomembranous colitis revealed by lower gastro-intestinal endoscopy or Computed Tomography;
4. Colonic histopathology characteristic of C. difficile infection (with or without diarrhoea or toxin detection) on a specimen obtained during endoscopy or colectomy;

5. Faecal specimens collected post-mortem where the specimen is C. difficile toxin positive or tissue specimens collected post-mortem where pseudomembranous colitis is revealed or colonic histopathology is characteristic of C. difficile infection."¬Public Health England (PHE)¬"https://www.gov.uk/government/statistics/clostridium-difficile-infection-monthly-data-by-nhs-acute-trust

393¬Mental health OAP placements 3 month rolling¬Number of mental health OAP bed days over 3 month rolling period¬"The number of bed days for inappropriate Out of Area Placements (OAP) in mental health services for adults in non-specialist acute inpatient care over 3 month rolling period.

There is no operational standard"¬The Government set a national ambition to eliminate inappropriate OAPs in mental health services for adults in acute inpatient care by 2020-21. Inappropriate OAPs are where patients are sent out of area because no bed is available for them locally
column2: which can delay their recovery. It is essential to collect OAPs data in order to monitor progress towards achieving the ambition and to understand where and why OAPs are happening. Having this information is critical to improving patient care and ultimately eliminating the practice of inappropriately sending patients out of area to receive acute inpatient care.¬The number of bed days due to inappropriate out of area bed days for adult non specialist acute mental health care.¬N/A¬"An OAP is when a patient with assessed acute mental health needs who requires non-specialised inpatient care (CCG commissioned)
column3: is admitted to a unit that does not form part of the usual local network of services. This includes inpatient units that:

column1: a) are not run by the patients home mental health care provider
column2: regardless of distance travelled or whether the admitting unit is run by an NHS or Independent Sector Provider (ISP);

column1: b) are not intended to admit people living in the catchment of the persons local community mental health team (CMHT);
c) are located in a place where the person cannot be visited regularly by their care coordinator to ensure continuity of care and effective discharge planning.
Non-specialised (CCG commissioned) inpatient acute mental health care includes the following bed types:
 Acute adult mental health care
 Acute older adult mental health care (organic and functional)

 Psychiatric Intensive Care Unit (acute mental health care)"¬NHS Digital: Mental Health OAP collection¬"https://digital.nhs.uk/data-and-information/clinical-audits-and-registries/out-of-area-placements-oaps

column1: Performance is mapped from provider to Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG)"¬"A&E waiting times form part of the NHS Constitution. Operational standard is 95%"¬Total number of patients who have a total time in A&E within 4 hours from arrival to admission
column2: transfer or discharge (all types of A&E)¬Total number of A&E attendances (all types of A&E)¬"The following fields from A&E attendances and emergency admissions monthly return (MSitAE) via Strategic Data Collection Service (SDCS) are required to construct the numerator: Number of A&E attendances (all types of A&E); Number of A&E attendances within 4 hours from arrival to admission

column1: The following fields from A&E Hospital Episode Statistics (for mapping to CCG) are required to construct the denominator: Number of A&E attendances (all types of A&E).
Mapping A&E 4 hour standard from provider to CCG:

HES A&E data is used to estimate what proportion of activity from a provider can be attributed to each CCG. These proportions are applied to both numerator and denominator (provider based monthly collection figures on breaches and attendances) to assign numbers to each CCG. A limit of 1% is used
column2: so any percentages of less than 1% for a mapping to a CCG are ignored in the calculations. Thus the numbers of attendances / breaches does not correspond to the actual figures and should only be used as a basis for estimating performance."¬"NHS England: A&E attendances and emergency admissions monthly return.

column1: 412¬Cancer patients seen within 2 weeks (%)¬Percentage of cancer patients seen within 14 days from an urgent GP referral for suspected cancer to a first consultant appointment¬"Percentage of patients seen within 14 days from an urgent GP referral for suspected cancer to a first consultant appointment.

Cancer waiting times performance is assessed using quarterly data.  Monthly data is also collected but this is provisional and is subject to change as records are validated within the quarter.  As a consequence the sum of the standalone published monthly data for a given quarter does not equal the equivalent standalone quarterly published data.  Data items represent the latest finalised quarterly performance data as well as the most recent monthly provisional data in order to show an indication of the progress within the quarter.  Operational standards only apply to quarterly data aggregated for all tumour categories."¬To ensure Providers and Clinical Commissioning Groups (CCGs) achieve and maintain the Constitution standard for waiting times from urgent GP referral for suspected cancer to  date first seen for all suspected cancers. 416¬Starting treatment for psychosis within two weeks of referral by CCG (%)¬Percentage of people with first episode of psychosis starting treatment with a NICE-recommended package of care treated within 2 weeks of referral by CCG¬The percentage of people referred to service experiencing first episode psychosis or at risk mental state that start a NICE-recommended care package in the reporting period.
All activity relating to people who receive specialist secondary mental health care services and have
column2: or are thought to have
column3: a mental illness; or who receive specialist secondary learning disabilities or autism spectrum disorder services and have
column4: or are thought to have
column5: a learning disability or autism spectrum disorder is within scope. Children and adolescents (including those with a learning disability and/or autism spectrum disorder) under the age of 18 are also included where they are in receipt of care from a specialist secondary mental health
column6: learning disabilities or autism spectrum disorder service or an early intervention service. Children and young people in receipt of psychological therapies covered under the CYP (Children and Young Peoples) IAPT (Improving Access to Psychological Therapies) programme are included within the scope.

column1: Operational standard is 56% from 1 April 2019. Rising to 60% from 1 April 2020"¬To encourage compliance with the new access and waiting time standard. This standard came into effect on 1 April 2016 and required that more than 50% of people experiencing first episode psychosis will be treated with a NICE-concordant package of care within 2 weeks of referral rising to 60% by 1 April 2020.¬The number of people referred to the service experiencing first episode psychosis or at risk mental state that start treatment within 2 weeks of referral in the reporting period¬The number of people referred to the service experiencing first episode psychosis or at risk mental state that start treatment in the reporting period¬"Two conditions must be met for the waiting time standard to be deemed to have been achieved:
1. A maximum wait of two weeks from referral to treatment; and
2. Treatment delivered in accordance with NICE guidelines for psychosis and
schizophrenia - either in children and young people CG155 (2013) https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/CG155 or in adults CG178 (2014) https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/CG178 (last accessed 18 June 2019).
Most initial episodes of psychosis occur between early adolescence and age 25 but the standard applies to people of all ages in line with NICE guidance.
Exemptions from accessing EIP services are referrals of people who are experiencing psychotic symptoms with a confirmed organic cause
column2: for example brain diseases such as Huntingtons and Parkinsons disease
column3: HIV or syphilis
column4: dementia
column5: or brain tumours or cysts."¬Mental Health Services Data Set (MHSDS)¬"https://www.england.nhs.uk/statistics/statistical-work-areas/eip-waiting-times/

Operational standard is 75%"¬"Improving Access to Psychological Therapies (IAPT) is an NHS programme in England that

offers interventions approved by the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) for treating people with depression or anxiety. NICE-recommended therapies are delivered by a single competent clinician
column2: with or without prescribed medication."¬Number of ended referrals that finish a course of treatment in the reporting period who received their first treatment appointment within 6 weeks of referral.¬Number of ended referrals that finish a course of treatment in the reporting period.¬"Relevant IAPT data items and the permissible values for each data item are defined in the IAPT Data Standard. Psychological therapy: NICE recommended treatment from a qualified psychological therapist (low or high intensity). Referral date: The date a referral for assessment or treatment is received at the IAPT service or appointment processing agency such as single point of access or triage service. Treatment session: This is coded as Appointment Type 02  Treatment
column3: 03 - Assessment and Treatment
column4: and 05 - Review and Treatment in the IAPT data standard. Finished course of treatment: This is a count of all those who have left treatment having attended at least two treatment contacts

419¬Mixed sex accommodation breaches¬Number of mixed sex accommodation breaches¬"Number of breaches of mixed-sex accommodation (MSA) sleeping accommodation.

column1: Operational standard is 0."¬Patients who have experienced MSA say they felt this compromised their privacy and a dignity at a time when they already felt vulnerable and this was a concern for them. Monitoring breaches of the guidance means that organisations will be held to account for managing beds and facilities to eliminate occurrences of MSA. It also better facilitates commissioners application of sanctions to NHS organisations that breach the guidance. Publication of the associated breach data means that patients and the public will be better informed about an organisations progress in eliminating MSA.¬Number of MSA breaches for the reporting month¬N/A¬"As well as monitoring and reporting all unjustified mixing of sleeping accommodation

column1: Operational standard is 80%"¬The burden of COPD is enormous and is increasing
column2: but early
column3: accurate diagnosis in a primary care setting can have a crucial impact on managing the condition. New National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidelines and the General Medical Services (GMS) Contract
column4: with incentives
column5: give GPs and practice nurses the opportunity to diagnose COPD patients and manage them in a structured fashion. Failure to identify cases early in the progression of the disease will impact on sensitivity to treatment
column6: increase secondary care requirements and reduce quality of life. There is no single diagnostic test for COPD. Making a diagnosis relies on clinical judgement
column7: based on a combination of history
column8: physical examination and confirmation of airflow obstruction using spirometry. This indicator measures the proportion of people who have had their diagnosis confirmed by post-bronchodilator spirometry within 1 year of diagnosis. This aims to support the correct diagnosis in people with COPD.¬Number of patients on the quality and outcomes framework (QOF) register for COPD in whom the diagnosis has been confirmed by post bronchodilator spirometry between 3 months before and 12 months after entering on to the register¬Number of patients on the QOF register for COPD¬"The following fields are required from QOF:  Numerator field for the referenced indicator (as NUMERATOR); Denominator field for the referenced indicator (as DENOMINATOR)

column1: Operational standard is 70%"¬"Asthma is a common but variable condition which responds well to appropriate management and which is principally managed in primary care. Much of the variation in emergency admission to secondary care is due to a range of factors in the provision of a primary care
column2: and to patients understanding of their condition (and thus the ability to self-manage). Symptomatic asthma control is best assessed using directive questions such as the RCP three questions. Proactive structured review
column3: as opposed to opportunistic or unscheduled review
column4: is associated with reduced exacerbation rate and days lost from normal activity. The RCP three questions is an effective way of assessing a persons asthma control:

column1: In the last month:
1. Have you had difficulty sleeping because of your asthma symptoms (including
cough)?
2. Have you had your usual asthma symptoms during the day (cough
column2: wheeze
column3: chest

column1: tightness or breathlessness)?
3. Has your asthma interfered with your usual activities (for example housework
column2: work or

column1: school)?
Answering No to all three questions is consistent with controlled asthma."¬Number of patients with asthma
column2: on the register

column1: Operational standard is 96%

¬Patients with long-term conditions (LTC) such as asthma, diabetes, COPD and cardiovascular disease, exacerbate their long-term conditions by smoking. Smoking cessation is recommended as an intervention for effective self-management of these conditions. GPs (and other healthcare professionals) have an opportunity to influence to change a patients behaviour. Smoking cessation interventions are a cost-effective way of reducing health inequalities. Quitting at any age provides both immediate and long-term health benefits. If those with comorbidities continue to smoke, their risks of further health problems are increased and health outcomes and quality of life is likely to be reduced.¬Number of current smokers with LTCs offered support in last 12 months¬Number of patients with a LTC who are current smokers, as recorded in last 12 months¬The following fields are required from QOF:  Numerator field for the referenced indicator (as NUMERATOR); Denominator field for the referenced indicator (as DENOMINATOR)

column1: Operational standard is 78%"¬Diabetes mellitus (DM) is one of the common endocrine diseases affecting all age groups. The Public Health England (PHE) diabetes prevalence model of 2015 estimated 3.8 million people over the age of 16 in England had diabetes (either diagnosed or undiagnosed). The direct costs of diabetes approach almost 10 per cent of the NHS budget
column2: £8 billion of which is spent on managing preventable complications associated with the condition. These complications include premature death and disability because diabetes doubles the risk of heart attack and stroke
column3: and substantially increases the risk of kidney disease
column4: blindness and amputations. Effective control and monitoring can reduce mortality and morbidity. It is clear from best practice guidance that general practice plays a pivotal and significant contribution to the effective management of diabetes and should encompass awareness of risk factors and symptoms
column5: prompt and appropriate referral
column6: and holistic assessment. Blood pressure lowering in people with diabetes reduces the risk of macrovascular and microvascular disease. There is well established evidence that good control of blood pressure
column7: low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol and blood glucose significantly improves cardiovascular disease outcomes. This is discussed further in a recent United States study which describes cardiovascular disease (CVD)
column8: including coronary heart disease
column10: and heart failure
column11: as predominant causes of morbidity and mortality among persons with DM.¬Number of diabetes patients where last BP is 140/80 mmHg or less¬Number of patients on the quality and outcomes framework (QOF) register for Diabetes¬"The following fields are required from QOF:  Numerator field for the referenced indicator (as NUMERATOR); Denominator field for the referenced indicator (as DENOMINATOR)

column1: 457¬Hypertension BP reading 150/90mmHg or less by GP practice (%)¬Percentage of patients with hypertension in whom the last blood pressure reading measured in the preceding 12 months is 150/90 mmHg or less by GP Practice¬"The percentage of patients with hypertension in whom the last blood pressure reading measured in the preceding 12 months is 150/90 mmHg or less
Operational standard is 80%

¬In primary care, it is prudent to connect heart disease and stroke because the primary care prevention and routine management as these conditions is broadly the same. This holistic approach aligns with the approach taken across NHS England and Public Health England. The Next Steps in the 5 Year Forward View identifies cardiovascular disease (CVD) prevention as one of the sustainability must-dos for Clinical Commissioning Groups (CCGs). In support of this, the RightCare CVD prevention programme is now rolling out to all CCGs with a specific focus on improving the detection and treatment of hypertension and atrial fibrillation (AF). This indicator measures the intermediate health outcome of a blood pressure of 150/90mmHg or less in patients with hypertension and coronary heart disease (CHD). Its intent is to promote the secondary prevention of CVD through satisfactory blood pressure control. The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guideline on hypertension recommends a target blood pressure below 140/90 mmHg in patients aged 79 or under with treated hypertension and a clinic blood pressure below 150/90 mmHg in patients aged 80 or over, with treated hypertension. For the purpose of quality and outcome framework (QOF), an audit standard of 150/90 mmHg has been adopted for this indicator.¬Number of patients with hypertension in whom the last blood pressure reading measured in the preceding 12 months is 150/90 mmHg or less¬Number of patients on the quality outcomes framework (QOF) register for Hypertension¬The following fields are required from QOF:  Numerator field for the referenced indicator (as NUMERATOR); Denominator field for the referenced indicator (as DENOMINATOR)

column1: 464¬Dementia Face to Face review by GP practice (%)¬"Percentage of patients diagnosed with dementia whose care plan has been reviewed in a face-to-face review in the preceding 12 months by GP Practice
¬The percentage of patients diagnosed with dementia whose care plan has been reviewed in a face-to-face review in the preceding 12 months
Operational standard is 70%"¬Dementia is a progressive and mostly irreversible clinical syndrome
column2: resulting in impairment of mental function. It is the leading cause of death in England
column3: accounting for 11.6% of all recorded deaths and represents one of the most significant challenges facing health and social care services in England today. An estimated 676
column4: 000 are living with the condition
column5: costing society an estimated £26 billion a year. People living with dementia should have regular face-to-face reviews of their care plan with an aim to encourage the coordinated delivery of health and social care services. Regular reviews are important because the needs of a person with dementia and their carers may change over time. National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidelines state that a face-to-face review allows primary care practitioners to fully assess the changing needs of people with dementia and their carers and ensure that coordination between health and social services is achieved. The 12 month timeframe has been selected in line with the frequency for review of social care plans recommended by the Department of Health. Regular reviews are important because the needs of a person with dementia and their carers may change over time. NICE guidelines state that a face-to-face review allows primary care practitioners to fully assess the changing needs of people with dementia and their carers and ensure that coordination between health and social services is achieved.¬Number of patients diagnosed with dementia whose care plan has been reviewed in a face-to-face review in the preceding 12 months¬Number of patients on the quality and outcome framework (QOF) register with Dementia¬"The following fields are required from QOF:  Numerator field for the referenced indicator (as NUMERATOR); Denominator field for the referenced indicator (as DENOMINATOR)

column1: 465¬Cancer Two Week Wait referrals by GP practice (%)¬Percentage of new cancer cases treated who were referred through the Two Week Wait referral route by GP Practice¬The percentage of new cancer cases treated who were referred through the Two Week Wait referral route¬For people with cancer an early diagnosis can improve survival prospects. Poor rates of early diagnosis are widely accepted to be the main reason the UK lags behind its peers when comparing cancer survival rates. Increasing the rate of early diagnosis has the potential to both improve health outcomes for patients and increase the cost effectiveness of NHS spend as spending on cancer treatment may be offset by cost savings elsewhere. Of the 290
column2: 000 cases of cancer diagnosed in the UK each year
column3: most will come via symptomatic presentation to primary care. The two week waiting time national target for suspected cancer urgent referrals was introduced in 2000 and this indicator represents a conversion rate of urgent referrals within the two week time frame to cancer diagnoses. As calculations are based on smaller numbers than other indicators in this set
column4: the chance of random variation is higher. Monitoring of the indicator over time is recommended.¬Number of patients registered at the practice who have a date of first treatment (i.e. with Cancer Treatment Event Type of 01 or 07) in the financial year on the Cancer Waiting Times system and who had a Referral Priority Type of 3 (Two Week Wait)
column5: excluding patients referred for non-cancer breast symptoms (Cancer Referral Type of 16).¬Total number of patients registered at the practice who have a date of first treatment (i.e. with 'Cancer Treatment Event Type' of 01 or 07) in the financial year on the Cancer Waiting Times system.¬"The following fields are required from PHE Fingertips GP Practice Profile: Domain is 'Cancer - TWW referrals'. column1: 466¬Cervical Screening by GP practice (%)¬"Percentage of women eligible for cervical screening at a given point in time who were screened adequately within a specified period by GP Practice
¬The percentage of women eligible for screening at a given point in time who were screened adequately within a specified period (within 3.5 years for women aged 25 to 49
column2: and within 5.5 years for women aged 50 to 64).

column1: Operational standard is 80%"¬Cervical cancer is the 17th most common cause of cancer death among females in the UK (2014)
column2: accounting for 1% of all cancer deaths in females. This is one of the few cancers that is preventable because pre-cancerous cell changes can be picked up before they have a chance to develop into cancer. While no cervical screening test can be 100% effective
column3: cervical screening programmes (CSPs) greatly reduce the incidence of this cancer in the screened population. Coverage in the CSP is currently falling year on year and this indicator enables a practice to monitor coverage and thus implement interventions to increase uptake where appropriate. Early detection of cervical abnormalities means that less invasive interventions can take place in out-patient settings
column4: often at a precancerous stage
column5: and the long term adverse impact on (often younger) womens lives is reduced.¬"Number of women eligible and screened in the age groups 25 to 49 and 50 to 64

column1: ¬Number of women eligible for screening in the age groups 25 to 49 and 50 to 64¬The following fields are required from Cervical Screening data:  Screened field (as NUMERATOR); Eligible field (as DENOMINATOR)
Exceptions relate to registered patients who are on the relevant disease register or in the target population group and would ordinarily be included in the indicator denominator
column2: but who are excepted on the basis of one or more of the exception criteria:

column1: Patients are removed from the denominator and numerator if they have been both excepted AND they have not received the care specified in the indicator wording;
If the patient has been excepted but subsequently the care has been carried out within the relevant time period
column2: the patient will be included in the numerator and denominator (achievement will always override an exception)."¬PHE Cervical Screening Programme
column3: NHS Digital. Age 25_49; Age 50_64¬"https://digital.nhs.uk/data-and-information/publications/statistical/cervical-screening-programme/cervical-screening-programme-coverage-statistics-management-information

column1: 471¬Naproxen and Ibuprofen prescription by GP practice (%)¬Percentage of prescription items for Naproxen and Ibuprofen by GP Practice¬Total number of prescription items for ibuprofen and naproxen as a percentage of the total number of prescription items for all Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).¬There are long-standing and well-recognised gastrointestinal and renal safety concerns with all NSAIDs. There is also an increased risk of cardiovascular events with many NSAIDs
column2: including COX-2 inhibitors and some traditional NSAIDs. The Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) recommends that the lowest effective dose of NSAID should be prescribed for the shortest time necessary for control of symptoms. In 2005
column3: a review by the European Medicines Agency identified an increased risk of thrombotic events
column4: such as heart attack and stroke
column5: with COX-2 inhibitors. In 2006
column6: they also concluded that a small increased risk of thrombotic events could not be excluded with nonselective NSAIDs
column7: including diclofenac
column8: particularly when they are used at high doses for long-term treatment. This risk does not appear to be shared by ibuprofen at 1200 mg per day or less
column9: or naproxen at 1000 mg per day. This indicator supports the Key therapeutic topics  Medicines management options for local implementation publication by highlighting variation in prescribing across organisations. It is intended to support organisations and prescribers in reviewing the appropriateness of current prescribing
column10: revising prescribing where appropriate and monitoring implementation. The goal is to help patients to improve their outcomes
column11: take their medicines correctly
column13: reduce wastage of medicines and improve medicines safety.¬Number of prescription items for ibuprofen and naproxen (sub-set of BNF section 10.1.1) prescribed during the last four Quarters¬Number of prescription items for all NSAIDS
column14: BNF section 10.1.1 (non-steroidal ant-inflammatory drugs) prescribed during the last four Quarters¬"The following fields are required from NHS BSA:  Numerator field for the referenced indicator (as NUMERATOR); Denominator field for the referenced indicator (as DENOMINATOR).

column1: The indicator covers a rolling year so Numerator and Denominator are each the sum of the last four quarters.
Exceptions relate to registered patients who are on the relevant disease register or in the target population group and would ordinarily be included in the indicator denominator
column2: but who are excepted on the basis of one or more of the exception criteria:

column1: Patients are removed from the denominator and numerator if they have been both excepted AND they have not received the care specified in the indicator wording;
If the patient has been excepted but subsequently the care has been carried out within the relevant time period
column2: the patient will be included in the numerator and denominator (achievement will always override an exception)."¬NHS Business Services Authority 97¬By email from NHS Business Services Authority¬GP Practice¬Quarterly¬(+45 days)¬Net¬NHS Business Services Authority 97¬By email from NHS Business Services Authority¬GP Practice¬Quarterly¬(+45 days)¬Net¬In publication¬"Total number of prescription items for ibuprofen and naproxen divided by the number of prescription items for all NSAIDS
column3: expressed as a percentage.

column1: 473¬Antibacterial Items/Star Pu rate by GP practice¬Rate of prescription items for antibacterial drugs per Oral antibacterial ITEM based on STAR-PU by GP Practice¬"Number of prescription items for antibacterial drugs (BNF 5.1) per Oral antibacterial (BNF 5.1 sub-set) ITEM based Specific Therapeutic Group Age-sex weightings Related Prescribing Unit (STAR-PU).
Operational standard is 1.61 (2017/18) and 0.965 (2018/19)"¬"Antibiotic resistance poses a significant threat to public health
column2: especially because antibiotics underpin routine medical practice. To help prevent the development of

column1: resistance it is important to only prescribe antibiotics when they are necessary
column2: and not for self-limiting mild infections such as colds and most coughs
column3: sinusitis
column4: earache and sore throats. HPA guidance recommends that simple generic antibiotics should be used if possible when antibiotics are necessary. Broad-spectrum antibiotics (for example
column5: co-amoxiclav
column6: quinolones and cephalosporin's) should be avoided when narrow-spectrum antibiotics remain effective because they increase the risk of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)
column7: Clostridium difficile and resistant urinary tract infections. This indicator supports the Key therapeutic topics  Medicines management options for local implementation publication by highlighting variation in prescribing across organisations. It is intended to support organisations and prescribers in reviewing the appropriateness of current prescribing
column8: revising prescribing where appropriate and monitoring implementation. The goal is to help patients to improve their outcomes
column10: avoid taking unnecessary medicines
column11: reduce wastage of medicines and improve medicines safety."¬Total number of prescription items for Antibacterial drugs (BNF 5.1) prescribed during the last four Quarters.¬Total number of Oral antibacterial (BNF 5.1 sub-set) ITEM based STAR-PUs¬"The following fields are required from NHS BSA:  Numerator field for the referenced indicator (as NUMERATOR); Denominator field for the referenced indicator (as DENOMINATOR).

column1: 478¬Emergency Asthma Admissions rate per 100 patients by GP practice¬Rate of emergency asthma admissions per 100 patients on the practice disease register for Asthma by GP Practice¬Emergency Asthma admissions per 100 patients on the practice disease register for Asthma¬Asthma is the most common long term medical condition among children and young people in UK. Unfortunately there are a number of avoidable deaths in children and young people from asthma every year. column2: there were 24
column3: 744 emergency admissions for asthma
column4: and 21 children under 14 years died from asthma in 2012. Preventable factors were identified in 90% of childhood deaths from Asthma. Asthma responds well to appropriate management and which is principally managed in primary care. column1: 482¬Emergency Dementia Admissions rate per 100 patients by GP practice¬Rate of emergency dementia admissions per 100 patients on the practice disease register for dementia by GP practice¬Emergency Dementia admissions per 100 patients on the practice disease register for Dementia¬Dementia is a progressive and mostly irreversible clinical syndrome
column2: resulting in impairment of mental function. It is the leading cause of death in England
column3: accounting for 11.6% of all recorded deaths and represents one of the most significant challenges facing health and social care services in England. Figures obtained by the Alzheimers Society and MHP Health Mandate have revealed a 12% rise in the number of emergency hospital admissions for people with dementia since 2006
column4: costing the NHS an additional £2.8 million. Co-ordinated health and social care interventions can help prevent unwarranted admission to hospital. People living with dementia should have regular face-to-face reviews of their care plan with an aim to encourage the coordinated delivery of health and social care services. Regular reviews are important because the needs of a person with dementia and their carers may change over time. National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidelines state that a face-to-face review allows primary care practitioners to fully assess the changing needs of people with dementia and their carers and ensure that coordination between health and social services is achieved.¬Total number of inpatient spells started during the last four complete Quarters for patients with an emergency method of admission (excluding via Mental Health Crisis Resolution Team) and with the primary diagnosis between 'F00' and 'F03'¬Number of patients on the quality and outcome framework (QOF) register for Dementia¬"The following fields are required from HES:  Admidate

column1: 490¬Overall Exception Rate by GP practice¬Rate of overall exception across all QOF indicators by GP Practice¬"Overall Exception rate across all quality and outcome framework (QOF) indicators.
QOF indicators available at:
https://digital.nhs.uk/data-and-information/publications/statistical/quality-and-outcomes-framework-achievement-prevalence-and-exceptions-data/
Last accessed 18 February 2019"¬Exception reporting applies to indicators in any domain of the QOF
column2: where the achievement is determined by the percentage of patients receiving the specified level of care. Exceptions are patients who are on the disease register and who would ordinarily be included in an indicator denominator. However they are excepted from the indicator denominator because they meet at least one of the exception criteria set out in the General Medical Services Statement of Financial Entitlements. Therefore
column3: a practice with a high overall exception rate may be due to a variety of these criteria having been met. Exception reporting exists to help ensure practices are not financially penalised when the reason for non-achievement is beyond their control. Although patients may be excepted from the denominator
column4: they should still be the recipients of best clinical care and practice. The duty of care remains for all patients
column5: irrespective of exception reporting arrangements. Where this indicator is provided for quality improvement rather than service payment; therefore there should be no exception reporting and a high exception rate may act as a prompt to support further local conversations as to why this may be. Contractors may be called on to explain why they have excepted patients from an indicator and have a high exception rate.¬Sum of the Exceptions for all QOF indicators¬Sum of the Denominators for all QOF indicators plus the Sum of the Exceptions for all QOF indicators¬The following fields are required from QOF:  Total no. of exceptions across all indicators (as NUMERATOR);  Total denominators plus total exceptions for all indicators (as DENOMINATOR)¬QOF¬"https://digital.nhs.uk/data-and-information/publications/statistical/quality-and-outcomes-framework-achievement-prevalence-and-exceptions-data

column1: Criteria used by NHS organisations to determine staff eligibility for inclusion in the survey are:

All full-time and part-time staff who were directly employed by the organisation on  the annual census day of 1 September; Staff on fixed-term contracts; Staff on secondment to a different organisation
column2: but only if they were still being paid by the participating organisation and had been out on secondment for less than one year; Hosted staff (staff seconded to the participating organisation from elsewhere
column3: e.g. social care staff seconded from the local authority) who had a substantive contract with the organisation
column4: but only if they were on the participating organisations payroll
column5: and were being paid by the participating organisation; Any staff member who met the above criteria who was on parental leave (maternity or paternity leave).

column1: The staff list excludes:

Staff who started working at the organisation after the annual census day of 1 September; Staff who were on long-term sick leave (at least 90 days) on 1 September; Staff on unpaid career breaks; All staff employed by sub-contracted organisations or outside contractors; Bank or locum staff (unless they also had substantive organisation contracts); Seconded staff who were not being paid by the participating organisation; Student nurses; Non-executive directors; Staff who worked under a retention of employment (RoE) model."¬NHS Staff Survey¬"http://www.nhsstaffsurveys.com/Page/1064/Latest-Results/2018-Results/

column1: Criteria used by NHS organisations to determine staff eligibility for inclusion in the survey are:

All full-time and part-time staff who were directly employed by the organisation on  the annual census day of 1 September; Staff on fixed-term contracts; Staff on secondment to a different organisation
column2: but only if they were still being paid by the participating organisation and had been out on secondment for less than one year; Hosted staff (staff seconded to the participating organisation from elsewhere
column3: e.g. social care staff seconded from the local authority) who had a substantive contract with the organisation
column4: but only if they were on the participating organisations payroll
column5: and were being paid by the participating organisation; Any staff member who met the above criteria who was on parental leave (maternity or paternity leave).

column1: The staff list excludes:

Staff who started working at the organisation after the annual census day of 1 September; Staff who were on long-term sick leave (at least 90 days) on 1 September; Staff on unpaid career breaks; All staff employed by sub-contracted organisations or outside contractors; Bank or locum staff (unless they also had substantive organisation contracts); Seconded staff who were not being paid by the participating organisation; Student nurses; Non-executive directors; Staff who worked under a retention of employment (RoE) model."¬NHS Staff Survey¬"http://www.nhsstaffsurveys.com/Page/1064/Latest-Results/2018-Results/

Cancer waiting times performance is assessed using quarterly data.  Monthly data is also collected but this is provisional and is subject to change as records are validated within the quarter.  As a consequence the sum of the standalone published monthly data for a given quarter does not equal the equivalent standalone quarterly published data.  Data items represent the latest finalised quarterly performance data as well as the most recent monthly provisional data in order to show an indication of the progress within the quarter. column1: 698¬Cancer patients seen within 2 weeks (%)¬Percentage of cancer patients seen within 14 days from an urgent GP referral for suspected cancer to a first consultant appointment by Provider¬"Percentage of patients seen within 14 days from an urgent GP referral for suspected cancer to a first consultant appointment.

Cancer waiting times performance is assessed using quarterly data.  Monthly data is also collected but this is provisional and is subject to change as records are validated within the quarter.  As a consequence the sum of the standalone published monthly data for a given quarter does not equal the equivalent standalone quarterly published data.  Data items represent the latest finalised quarterly performance data as well as the most recent monthly provisional data in order to show an indication of the progress within the quarter.  Operational standards only apply to quarterly data aggregated for all tumour categories."¬To ensure Providers and Clinical Commissioning Groups (CCGs) achieve and maintain the Constitution standard for waiting times from urgent GP referral for suspected cancer to  date first seen for all suspected cancers. The indicator is a core delivery indicator that maximum two week wait from urgent GP (GMP
column2: GDP or Optometrist) referral for suspected cancer to first outpatient attendance. ¬Patients urgently referred with suspected cancer by their GP (GMP
column3: GDP or Optometrist) who were first seen within 14 calendar days within the given month¬All patients urgently referred with suspected cancer by their GP (GMP
column4: GDP or Optometrist) who were first seen within the given month¬"The following data fields in the Cancer Waiting Times Database (CWT-Db) are used to construct the indicator: PERIOD; YEAR; DCO; CCG; ProviderCode; CancerReportCategory NoSeen; DaysWithin14; Days15to16; Days17to21; Days22To28; DaysMoreThan28; STP

Cancer waiting times performance is assessed using quarterly data.  Monthly data is also collected but this is provisional and is subject to change as records are validated within the quarter.  As a consequence the sum of the standalone published monthly data for a given quarter does not equal the equivalent standalone quarterly published data.  Data items represent the latest finalised quarterly performance data as well as the most recent monthly provisional data in order to show an indication of the progress within the quarter.  Operational standards only apply to quarterly data aggregated for all tumour categories.

column1: Operational standard is 0."¬Patients who have experienced MSA say they felt this compromised their privacy and a dignity at a time when they already felt vulnerable and this was a concern for them. Monitoring breaches of the guidance means that organisations will be held to account for managing beds and facilities to eliminate occurrences of MSA. It also better facilitates commissioners application of sanctions to NHS organisations that breach the guidance. Publication of the associated breach data means that patients and the public will be better informed about an organisations progress in eliminating MSA.¬Number of MSA breaches for the reporting month¬N/A¬"As well as monitoring and reporting all unjustified mixing of sleeping accommodation
column2: NHS Trusts are also required to monitor all justified mixing in sleeping accommodation
column3: all mixed-sex sharing of bathroom / toilet facilities (including passing through accommodation or toilet / bathroom facilities used by the opposite gender)
column4: and all mixed provision of day space in mental health units at a local level. For practical reasons
column5: central reporting has been mandated for MSA breaches in respect of sleeping accommodation only.

Operational standard is 0"¬"The risk of healthcare acquired infections to patients should be reduced. While there are a number of factors that may increase the risk of acquiring an infection
column2: high standards of hygiene and cleanliness can minimise the risk of occurrence. A high incidence of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) compared to the national rate may indicate issues with the Trusts infection control procedures. Specialist Trusts are not included due to case mix and small numbers. The UK government has a zero-tolerance approach to avoidable healthcare associated infections.

column1: Screening for MRSA should be carried out on all patients admitted to high risk units (defined as vascular

column10: Coronary Care Units]) and all patients previously identified as colonised with or infected by MRSA.

column1: In addition

column3: according to provision of specialised services (e.g. transplant
column4: neonatal)
column5: and units with a history of high endemicity of MRSA. Local risk assessment may increase the proportion of detected MRSA colonised individuals

column1: Specialist Trusts are not included due to case mix and small numbers."¬Number of incidences of Clostridium difficile (total cases) or the number of incidences of Clostridium difficile (Trust apportioned cases)¬N/A¬"Any of the following defines a C. difficile infection case in patients aged 2 years and above and must be reported to the Health Protection Agency:
1. Diarrhoeal stools (Bristol Stool types 5-7) where the specimen is C. difficile toxin positive;
2. Toxic megacolon or ileostomy where the specimen is C. difficile toxin positive;
3. Pseudomembranous colitis revealed by lower gastro-intestinal endoscopy or Computed Tomography;
4. Colonic histopathology characteristic of C. difficile infection (with or without diarrhoea or toxin detection) on a specimen obtained during endoscopy or colectomy;

5. Faecal specimens collected post-mortem where the specimen is C. difficile toxin positive or tissue specimens collected post-mortem where pseudomembranous colitis is revealed or colonic histopathology is characteristic of C. difficile infection."¬Public Health England (PHE)¬"https://www.gov.uk/government/statistics/clostridium-difficile-infection-monthly-data-by-nhs-acute-trust

Mapping A&E 4 hour standard from provider to CCG:

HES A&E data is used to estimate what proportion of activity from a provider can be attributed to each CCG. These proportions are applied to both numerator and denominator (provider based monthly collection figures on breaches and attendances) to assign numbers to each CCG. A limit of 1% is used
column2: so any percentages of less than 1% for a mapping to a CCG are ignored in the calculations. Thus the numbers of attendances / breaches does not correspond to the actual figures and should only be used as a basis for estimating performance."¬NHS England: A&E attendances and emergency admissions monthly return.¬"https://www.england.nhs.uk/statistics/statistical-work-areas/ae-waiting-times-and-activity/

770¬Cancer 62-day waits- urgent GP referral¬Percentage of cancer patients given a first treatment within 62 days from an urgent GP referral for suspected cancer by provider¬Percentage of patients given a first treatment within 62 days from an urgent GP referral for suspected cancer.

Cancer waiting times performance is assessed using quarterly data.  Monthly data is also collected but this is provisional and is subject to change as records are validated within the quarter.  As a consequence the sum of the standalone published monthly data for a given quarter does not equal the equivalent standalone quarterly published data.  Data items represent the latest finalised quarterly performance data as well as the most recent monthly provisional data in order to show an indication of the progress within the quarter.  Operational standards only apply to quarterly data aggregated for all tumour categories.
Tumour types are breast
column2: urological (excluding testicular)
column3: lower gastrointestinal (GI)
column4: skin
column5: lung and all cancer.
